Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Second Arterial Conduit Use in Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting

Background: The impact of a second arterial conduit on outcomes after multi-vessel coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) is uncertain. This study evaluates the effect of using a second arterial conduit compared to a venous conduit.

Methods: This randomised controlled trial was conducted using a state-maintained clinical registry from 126 non-federal hospitals in California. Participants were patients undergoing primary, isolated multi-vessel CABG with the left internal thoracic artery between 2006 and 2011. The intervention group received a second arterial conduit (right internal thoracic artery or radial artery), while the control group received a venous conduit. The primary outcome was all-cause mortality at 7 years. Propensity score matching was used to create comparable groups.

Results: A total of 5,866 patients received a second arterial conduit, and 53,566 received a venous conduit. Second arterial conduit use decreased from 10.7% in 2006 to 9.1% in 2011. The intervention group had significantly lower mortality (13.1% vs. 10.6%; HR 0.79, 95% CI 0.72–0.87) and reduced risks of myocardial infarction (HR 0.78, 95% CI 0.70–0.87) and repeat revascularization (HR 0.82, 95% CI 0.76–0.88). Right internal thoracic artery grafts had similar mortality to radial artery grafts but increased sternal wound infection risk (risk difference 1.07%, 95% CI 0.15%–2.07%).

Interpretation: Second arterial conduits are associated with improved outcomes in CABG. The radial artery may be preferred due to lower infection risk. Trial registration: Not provided. Funding: Not reported.
